## Installation and commands
### Clone this project
``` bash
git clone https://github.com/cvtung/4N-powerful-blog-template.git
```

### Install all required packages
``` bash
npm install
```

### Run Nuxt development server
``` bash
npm run dev
```

### Static site

#### Generate static site
Build this project as a static site, generate all routes as a single HTML files (with CSS + Javascript). Your site will be exported to `dist/` folder
``` bash
npm run generate
```

#### Serve static site
Serve the `dist/` directory like your static hosting would do (Netlify, Vercel, Surge, etc), great for testing before deploying.
``` bash
npm run start
```

For more information, please read https://nuxtjs.org/docs/2.x/get-started/commands#target-static

### Analyze
This will visualize your bundles and show you libraries' size.
``` bash
npm run analyze
```

---
## Project development
This project use [Vue](https://vuejs.org/) and [Nuxt](https://nuxtjs.org/), please check their documentations if my simple guide is not enough for you.

### Config Netlify CMS
For full documentation, please visit https://www.netlifycms.org/docs/intro/
Edit `static/admin/config.yml` to change Netlify CMS for example adding more settings, change default value for fields, ...

### Content
If you create something with Netlify CMS and publish it, everything will saved in `content/` directory inside your repository, not your local directory. You must pull commits from Github after editing.

### Resources
Resources should be put in `static/` directory. 
There is a `img/` folder inside `static/` for image assets. When you want to use an image for your `img` element, you can set `src="/img/logo.png"`

### Pages
https://nuxtjs.org/docs/2.x/directory-structure/pages
Everything inside `pages/` directory should be a single page. I implemented dynamic page and sub-page mechanic so this directory is simple as below:
![Page directory](https://res.cloudinary.com/tungcv/image/upload/v1610594457/4N%20Powerful%20Blog%20Template/Tutorials/Development%20guides/page_directory_mevh9v.png "Page directory")

#### index.vue
This is the home page. It loads data from `content/pages/index.json`. You can change `index.json` by using Netlify CMS or replace this page completely by modifying my old code.

#### _slug.vue
This is dynamic page that renders level 1 pages. 
Everytime you vist a level 1 page (e.g `https://your-website-name.com/blog` or `https://your-website-name.com/about-me`), slug of this page will be extracted (`blog`, `about-me`). Then it will try to find file with path `content/pages/${this.slug}.json` or `content/categories/${this.slug}.json`. Depend on which file is found, page will render correspondingly.
- For single page from `content/pages`: show file content.
- For category page from `content/categories`: list all posts belong to this category.

#### _categories/_slug.vue
This is dynamic page that renders level 2 pages (posts of categories).
When you visit `https://your-website-name.com/blog/post`, slug `post` will be extracted (category name like `blog` can be exported too but it's not important). A file with path `content/posts/${this.slug}.json` should exist and page will load data from this file.

### Generate static pages for all routes
Because I have dynamic routes level 2 pages so when generate static site, I must map each file from `content/posts/` with its route.
Please see file `nuxt.config.js`, `generate` attribute. Basically, I get all available category names, all post information and check which post belong to which category and generate route with post data as payload. Payload will be used later inside `asyncData` function of `_categories/_slug.vue`

### Vuex
Store data for this site: https://vuex.vuejs.org/guide/
Implementation is in `store/index.js`. Data stored can be used inside any Vue component.

### Blog settings
Check `store/index.js`.
When Nuxt server initializes, it load settings from `content/settings/setting.json`.
You can create many other settings by changing `static/admin/config.yml` then load them with Vuex's `actions`.

### Navigation bar
Check `store/index.js`.
When Nuxt server initializes, it load all categories from `content/categories/` and all single pages from `content/pages` to create a list of level 1 pages. 
`TopBar` component will load level 1 pages and render navigations for you site.

### Markdown parser
I created a simple version of `markdown-it-vue` called [markdown-it-vue-minify](https://www.npmjs.com/package/markdown-it-vue-minify) without charts and Font Awesome because these packages are really heavy.
There are still some [issues](https://github.com/cvtung/markdown-it-vue-minify/issues), please help me fix them and maintain this package! üôá‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
